labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Other term instead of "constrained"?
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
From Tom's email:

I am not sure about introducing a new term 'constrained' when there exists a historic term 'application-limited'.  Is there a reason you are avoiding 'application-limited'?  'bounded' may also be a more commonly used term in this regard.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: My PR #3  tried to remove some of this - its would be possible to remove all use of constrained if we wish.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: I'll do that, I'll change everything to directly say "rate limited".

issues.title: Better distinguish from RFC 7661
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
From Tom's email:

It seems to me that RFC 7661 already claims the scope of operation when the TCP is application-limited, so perhaps this has to more clearly state that this is an alternative to letting congestion window grow and then performing CWV when needed.  It also seems that the first sentence in section 4.4.2 of RFC 7661 is what this draft specifically addresses:

```
   TCP congestion control allows a sender to accumulate a cwnd that
   would allow it to send a burst of segments with a total size up to
   the difference between the FlightSize and cwnd. 
```

Here, we are proposing that TCP congestion control not allow a sender to accumulate an unlimited cwnd, so perhaps this needs to be clarified more directly (e.g., "one could follow RFC 7661 and other RFCs and let cwnd accumulate to large values and then later perform CWV, or one could constrain the growth of cwnd during application-limited phases, or both.  This draft proposes guidelines for bounding the growth of cwnd during application-limited intervals.")

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Started in PR #3

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Sorry, this shouldn't have been closed, I was too eager to close things as I thought I need to create a new repo

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: I'm not sure what to do - right now there is an {XXX Explain the diferences... }  part in there. Could you have another stab at this to finish it off?  We could also just leave this standing as it is for now keep this update for the next rev...  @gorryfair please make an update or tell me it's ok to proceed without it. Thanks!

issues.title: Security Consideration.
issues.author: gorryfair
issues.body:
I agree with the content of the security considerations section, but I am unsure that this is a real security issue.

I think it might be wiser to move this text and assert something like: 

While congestion control issues could result in unwanted competing traffic, they do not directly result in security considerations. Transport protocols that provide authentication (including those using encryption) or that are carried over protocols that provide authentication, can protect the congestion control mechanisms from network attack.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Change applied in the version for the new repo

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Sorry, I closed this as I thought I need to make a new repo. Anyway, I did address this with a push to master - @gorryfair  could you check, and close the issue if you agree with my change?

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: ping :-)   this change is implemented, can we close this issue?

issues.title: Fix Linux kernel text
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
is_cwnd_limited implements what we want, just "hard-coded" and for slow start only, since kernel 3.16 which was published in August 2014.

See: https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v3.16/source/include/net/tcp.h#L985

The current text mis-represents Linux, and also talks about a weird old version number.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Good find, and we should cite and fix in a PR:-)

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Will do *very* soon, promise!

issues.title: QUIC pacing in RFC 9002
issues.author: gorryfair
issues.body:
We currently say: A sender that paces packets (see Section 7.7) might delay sending packets and not fully utilize the congestion window due to this delay. A sender SHOULD NOT consider itself application limited if it would have fully utilized the congestion window without pacing delay.

... Ah this is MUCH more complicated.
I suggest there are two uses of pacing by a transport protocol:
1. {Burst Mitigation}. QUIC and TCP recommend the use of pacing to avoid generating long bursts. 
This adds a small fixed delay after sending a burst of 10 contiguous packets, 
to avoid exceeding the interface buffers of network equipment. 
2. {Rate-Based Pacing}.
This pacing is designed to avoid triggering 
congestion by limiting the rate near that of the presumed bottleneck, as in BBR, Vegas.

The 1st doesn't really cause under use of cwnd, the latter can. Do we agree on this?

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body:
I disagree with your assessment - also because the burst mitigation stuff doesn't really exist anywhere that I'd know of?

I wonder where you have the 10 packets from, surely not from an RFC?   There's a fixed hardcoded 10 packet burst in Linux pacing, maybe that's what you think of?  but that's only the first 10 packets of IW (and repeating every 2^32 packets  :-D  ) and never again.

I think there are three possible approaches:
1) Just leave the statement there for now, knowing that this may need tweaking. I tend towards this.
2) Remove it.
3) Say something like [pacing to be discussed in a future version]

What should we do?

As a side note, I think that pacing might in fact not make a difference for senders implementing our maxFs rule - because this essentially allows to increase "as normal" on the basis of the last RTT, and pacing happens in sub-RTT time scales...  i.e., the rule should normally make a paced sender automatically apply the rules of a "greedy" sender, removing the need to even say something about pacing perhaps?

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
The 10 packets is the IW in quic, and burst mitigation is the reason this was chosen, and so max burst size is linked to this. I observed that this text was never greatly precise:-).

I think some quic implementations do  burst-mitigation; and some do rate-based pacing. 

So the part I feel uncomfortable in our test is the citation of sect 7.7. Could we just remove that cross reference?

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body:
Sure!  Just
```(see Section 7.7)```
and leave all else as it is?

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Curiously, "yes - please jusr delete the bracketed text" - because the statement is true of pacing in general:-).

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Ah, I see, I have this there because it's a textual quote. Well, we will be forgiven for removing that section reference...

issues.title: Scope: RFCs we update, not "CC in general"
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
[At IETF-119, concerns were raised](https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/119/materials/minutes-119-ccwg-01) about this document being specific to the "cwnd", and not applying to (primarily) rate-based controls such as BBR.

This may be due to text such as: "senders using a congestion controlled transport protocol... (MUST / SHOULD ...)"

I think we should update the wording to narrow the scope to specifically be about the updated RFCs only.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Or we can update the published RFCs, and then note in a separate section that rate-based methods (such as BBR) have similar needs, and explain a little how cwnd comstrains the rate based on measured CC information. There's no RFC for BBR, so a (sub)section in this style with guidance would perhaps be more appropriate than trying to craft words around the current rev of the ID(s)?

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: We can combine this with clarifications around pacing.

issues.title: Trim the list of possible RFCs to update
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body: ... because [it prompted the comment](https://datatracker.ietf.org/meeting/119/materials/minutes-119-ccwg-01): "We should remind ourselves that an option is to declare some specs as historic, because it doesn't have deployment. Rather than updating we may just say an RFC is historic, rather than waste effort".

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body:
I agree we ought to trim the list!!
However, to obsolete a spec., we'd need to discuss if the method is deployed/implemented - and that might be a hard call to identify dead work or work that needs to be obsoleted for stability. At least I'd avoid doing that work.
I think we could flip this and say "these specific specs are deployed..." and hence continue to say how to update them in this draft. 
We might then avoid to comment on the status of RFCs that *could perhaps* have been implemented somewhere, but where can't see significant momentum at present.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Yes, just stop mentioning them.

issues.title: Typos in the Introduction
issues.author: mohittahiliani
issues.body:
There are two typos in the first paragraph of Introduction:

conection --> connection
quic --> QUIC

issues.title: Definition of maxFS is repeated
issues.author: mohittahiliani
issues.body: maxFS is defined twice: once in Section 1.1 and then in Section 3 with the same statement -- "the largest value of FlightSize since the last time that cwnd was decreased. If cwnd has never been decreased, maxFS is the maximum value of FlightSize since the start of the data transfer."

issues.title: maxFS should only be valid for one RTT => fixed by master, if you agree?
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
IETF-120:

- Neal: The MaxFS could seem to be over a time longer than an RTT, so we could use evidence from minutes, hours, days ago to justify the increase of the cwnd now. I wonder if we want to structure it so you can only use the flight size in the most recent round trip time, that's how the Linux code is structured.
- Michael: New congestion window validation (CWV) controls this case, which is an Experimental spec. Either way this is just a SHOULD.

We can point at new-cwv more than we already do, but it's interesting that Neal says that "that's how the Linux code is structured". We should check how Linux pulls this off. Hint to self: see the function: tcp_is_cwnd_limited

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body:
Neal must have thought: because this isn't done in CA in Linux?  I don't know - the Linux check is here:
https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.11.3/source/include/net/tcp.h#L1387
and it's a check against max_packets_out, which is only written here:
https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.11.3/source/net/ipv4/tcp_output.c#L1930
which just implements the "max" function.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Ahhh, I closed this by accident, by issuing a push to master, not a new branch!   Please take a look at rule 3 and the last paragraph in section 3, both new - and if you dislike, propose a fix (or push to master like I did   :-)  )

comments.author: nealcardwell
comments.body:
> Neal must have thought: because this isn't done in CA in Linux? I don't know - the Linux check is here: https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.11.3/source/include/net/tcp.h#L1387 and it's a check against max_packets_out, which is only written here: https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.11.3/source/net/ipv4/tcp_output.c#L1930 which just implements the "max" function.

It doesn't just implement a "max" function. :-)

Note that the expression !before(tp->snd_una, tp->cwnd_usage_seq) checks whether a round trip has elapsed. If a round trip has elapsed, then it sets tp->max_packets_out = tp->packets_out. That means that tp->max_packets_out only reflects the number of packets out in the network over the time scale of the last round trip.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body:
Aha!!!  Thanks!

And: guilty as charged!   I admit, when I looked, I reacted to seeing this line with its "snd_una, ..." by thinking: "yeah, yeah, some seqno check, not so important" and then missed this. My sloppiness wasted your time here. I'm sorry and will try to be more careful in the future!

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: So it seems the fix to master is ok [private email among the authors, and also to the authors]. Closing this.

issues.title: Double check if it's worth updating RFC 9002
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
From IETF-120:
- Ian Swett: [RFC9002](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9002/) already has text similar to the words in the slides. Not sure it's worth bothering to update [RFC 9002](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9002/).

Maybe make it clearer *why* we update RFC 9002.

issues.title: Double check: is the boundary to new-cwv clear enough?
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
IETF-120:

- Matt Mathis: There needs to be a clear boundary between this work and new experimental CWND validation work.
- Michael: Exactly, that's what we're trying to do.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: I think it is. Our new rule #3 refers to CWND validation, but it's a MAY. Should we find a way to make this *even* clearer, or just close this issue?

issues.title: Suggestions from MM
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body:
I hope he doesn't mind me making this public here - I *really* doubt he would, so I'm just going ahead, it's easier to remember and discuss that way. Here it comes, from an email on 20.7.2024:


Michael, I really like your doc!

Can I suggest a slightly different and stronger direction?
1) Make maxFS central and add the timestamp of the most recent ACK that supports  (within 1 segment of) the current value of maxFS.  I will assume maxFStime.

Observe that maxFS and maxFStime can be precisely defined and  accurately estimated from a packet capture.

2) Generalize the "increase function", citing 5681 as an non-normative example

3) Change Increase rule 1 to:  Allow growth when maxFS matches cwnd and is within one RTT of maxFStime.  This specifically allows increases during application limited phases if there is a recent observation that cwnd fits in the pipe.   Although a completely different implementation, this is more closely aligned with the way that linux behaves.   This detail is known to be important to some applications.  e.g DASH video, when the chunk size is similar to the pipe size. 

4) Imagine in the future, recasting several other algorithms by replacing cwnd with time decaying filters applied to maxFS.   All such filters should probably decay in parallel, and represent estimates of the total acceleration of the cross traffic at the bottleneck.

Note that for a start/stop application, restart after idle can estimate the distribution of the cross traffic's acceleration.  This is the one part of CC where I would expect that simple ML might do better than a hand crafted algorithm.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body:
About item 1: This relates to item 3, where I disagree - and item 4 is based upon it.
About item 2: I think we're general enough - RFC 5681 is just used as an example. We have a normative reference only because we propose to update RFC 5681.
About item 3: Interesting, he says the same as Neal about Linux, but I fail to find that code (see #30). I think the time-proposed limit is overly conservative: what if maxFS is 30 segments in one RTT, and becomes 35 in the next, even though the sender is rate-limited?   Hence I think it's better to point at using pipeACK from RFC 7661 as a MAY (since this is an Experimental RFC).
About item 4: too conservative too, then?

issues.title: PS RFC: MAY use x from exp RFC y.... is this ok?
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body: This is about our new rule 3. Gotta check. Else, we need to rephrase this.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: At CCWG @ IETF-121, Lars Eggert said that this is okay to do. So, closing this issue.

issues.title: Include examples in "Discussion" section
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body: To better explain the point of rules 1 and 2.

issues.title: Avoid over-use of the word "limit" in rules
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body: ...as in "limit with limit(..)"  - especially in rule #3 where it's a different limit.

comments.author: mohittahiliani
comments.body:
In my opinion, the beginning of Section 3 can be simplified as below:

When FlightSize < cwnd, regardless of the current state of a congestion control algorithm, senders using a congestion-controlled transport protocol:

1. MUST include a constraint on the growth of cwnd
2. SHOULD cap cwnd to be no larger than limit(maxFS)
3. MAY restrict maxFS as min(maxFS, pipeACK), using "pipeACK" as defined in [RFC7661]

In rule #2, the function limit() returns the maximum cwnd value possible in one RTT based on the congestion control algorithm and the maxFS parameter. For example, with rule #2 applied to Slow Start, as specified in [[RFC5681](https://mwelzl.github.io/draft-ccwg-ratelimited-increase/draft-welzl-ccwg-ratelimited-increase.html#RFC5681)], limit(maxFS)=2*maxFS, such that equation 2 in [[RFC5681](https://mwelzl.github.io/draft-ccwg-ratelimited-increase/draft-welzl-ccwg-ratelimited-increase.html#RFC5681)] becomes:

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: I prefer the phrasing proposed by @mohittahiliani  - others?

issues.title: Section 1.1 - Terminology should cover the usage of pipeACK
issues.author: mohittahiliani
issues.body: Since pipeACK is an important variable in one of the three rules, it would be better to cover it in the Terminology section in my opinion.

issues.title: Implementation Note in A.1.1.
issues.author: mohittahiliani
issues.body: The 'Implementation Note' in A.1.1. cited from Page 8 of RFC 5681 might require some more explanation because this note is primarily related to ssthresh in RFC 5681. It would be good to add the details of how this could lead to the growth of cwnd when sender is rate-limited.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: The first two paragraphs of A 1.1 can be deleted, and the word "also" removed from the following sentence. Then this is easier to read. Thanks!

issues.title: Move some normative refs to informative
issues.author: mwelzl
issues.body: e.g. the DCCP RFC: we don't update it anymore, we just discuss it in the appendix. So why is it normative?

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: It doesn't look normative now.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: I meant, it's in the section of "Normative References"

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: I wasn't clear - I saw it in the Normative References section, and think it now ought to be informative.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: Done with a push to master. AGAIN - by accident, but I don't think this needs much discussion, so it should be fine.

issues.title: Considerations for Handling Persistent Rate-Limitation
issues.author: shaileshprabhu95
issues.body:
The draft provides well-defined rules for constraining _cwnd_ growth when the sender is rate-limited. However, in scenarios where the sender remains consistently below _maxFS_ for an extended period, additional guidance on how _cwnd_ should evolve over time could enhance clarity. Ensuring that _cwnd_ accurately reflects the available network capacity in such cases may help maintain efficient congestion control behavior.

**Potential Considerations**:

1. **Ensuring accurate _cwnd_ adaptation**: If a sender remains rate-limited for multiple RTTs, there may be value in specifying how _cwnd_ should evolve to avoid potential overestimation of network capacity.
2. **Clarifying the role of CWV (Congestion Window Validation)**: While RFC 7661 provides mechanisms for _cwnd_ validation, explicitly referencing its applicability in the context of persistent rate-limitation could be beneficial.
3. **Alignment with real network conditions**: Providing guidance on how _cwnd_ should adapt when rate-limitation persists for an extended period could help maintain an accurate reflection of the path’s characteristics.

**Proposed Enhancement**:

- Clarify whether an adjustment mechanism for _cwnd_ under prolonged rate-limitation is needed, and if so, how it should be handled.
- Consider referencing CWV from RFC 7661 more explicitly as a possible approach or suggest alternative guidance for such scenarios.
- Define conditions under which the sender might need to re-evaluate _cwnd_ to ensure alignment with actual network conditions.

These considerations could further strengthen the draft by ensuring that _cwnd_ behaves optimally even in cases of persistent rate-limitation.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: These suggestions are very high-level and generic; they don't *really* make sense (we do address these things appropriately already). I have a strong suspicion that you used an LLM such as ChatGPT to produce this. That's a big waste of everyone's time, please stop.

pulls.title: Suggestion on rate-limited
pulls.author: gorryfair
pulls.body: Tried to improve the spec language.

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body: Many useful updates, thanks!  I made a few changes which I'll self-approve now (typos, undoing a small fix in text that is a quote, etc.). Then, I'll go ahead and change our text to talk about "rate-limited"

comments.body:
```suggestion
```
I take this out because I'll instead change all the terminology to rate-limited afterwards.

```suggestion
If the sender rate is limited for multiple RTTs, either by the sending application or by the receiving application, continuously increasing the cwnd would cause a mismatch between the cwnd and the capacity the path provides (i.e., over-estimating the capacity).
```

```suggestion
{{?RFC7661}} also suggests there is no increase limitation in the standard TCP behavior (which {{?RFC7661}} changes), on page 4:
```

```suggestion
- ns-2 allows cwnd to grow when it is rate-limited by rwnd. (Rate-limited by the sending application: not tested.)
```

```suggestion
  Specifically, for Linux kernel 2.6.11, an increase is only allowed if a function called `tcp_is_cwnd_limited` in `tcp.h` yields `true`. This function checks the flag `tp->is_cwnd_limited`, which is initialised to `false` in `tcp_output.c` and later set to `true` only if FlightSize is greater or equal to cwnd (`is_cwnd_limited |= (tcp_packets_in_flight(tp) >= tcp_snd_cwnd(tp))`).
```

```suggestion
>When bytes in flight is smaller than the congestion window and sending is not pacing limited, the congestion window is underutilized. This can happen due to insufficient application data or flow control limits. When this occurs, the congestion window SHOULD NOT be increased in either slow start or congestion avoidance.
```

Undoing this change because it's a literal quote from RFC 9002

```suggestion
With the exception of pacing, this specification conservatively limits the growth in cwnd, similar to Cubic and SCTP. The exception for pacing in the second paragraph requires the application to notify the transport layer that it paces packets. Pacing is typically done with delays below an RTT; thus, rule #2 in {{rules}} should cover this case without the need for such a notification from the application.
```

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body: I see an overlap with at least one of your PRs... would you agree that I should merge this first, and then resolve any conflicts? I think we want the Linux code description to be fixed in any case.

pulls.title: A small update to how we formulate our rules
pulls.author: mwelzl
pulls.body:
I think this is a little clearer. Agreed?

if you dislike "in some way", let's find a different way to say this: my point was to avoid immediately provoking the question "yes, but HOW?"  - or, even worse, letting people misinterpret it as "limit means: 'STOP HERE'  ".

comments.body:
MUST with /some way/ sounds fuzzy.
I guess the nearest could be:
/MUST include a way to limit.../
I like that!  I'll try this now and merge.  We should have a first version available soon, I think - we can always fine-tune the -01 draft much more  :-)

```suggestion
1. MUST include a way to limit the growth of cwnd when FlightSize < cwnd.
```

pulls.title: PR to position introduction
pulls.author: gorryfair
pulls.body: Might be a first shot at closing issue #2

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Thanks for tidying up the late-night edit into actual English!

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body: Thanks, looks good, just a few nits

comments.body:
```suggestion
It could also occur because the receiver has limited the flow control
```

No semantic reason, just trying to avoid "it is limited because it has limited"

```suggestion
(e.g., by the advertised TCP receiver window (rwnd) or by the connection or stream flow credit in quic).
```

```suggestion
but are related, because both describe the management of cwnd when the sender does not fully utilise the current cwnd.
```

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body: A suggestion, please feel free to reject it if I'm wrong... either way this is ok for me to merge afterwards!

comments.body:
```suggestion
Transport protocols that provide authentication (including those using encryption) or that are carried over protocols which provide authentication,
```

From what I once learned, "which" is right when the clause after it supplies extra information (rather than limiting a set). So... wouldn't it be ok here?  and this would avoid the triple use of "that".
I see, let's try and get this untangled, I'll rewrite.

pulls.title: Tom's suggested wording for the rules
pulls.author: mwelzl
pulls.body: To better allow for pacing. One change: I removed "or ECN marking" because I didn't think an ECN mark puts TCP into a "recovery state"?  and indeed, why would our rules not apply immediately after getting an ECN mark?  E.g., thinking of Prague, this doesn't necessarily mean a huge backoff.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body:
I see. I'm ok with not doing this update - e.g., there's also the possibility that we get an ok from the community to define the other MUST that Tom has sketched as a possibility:
"MUST not exceed 2*maxFS"   (I think, really, we'd want: "MUST not exceed cwnd + inc(maxFS)" - i.e., make the second rule a MUST and remove the first one).

Since this allows to increase more than some other protocol specs state and some implementations might do, it's perhaps ok with MUST as a limit for this. Anyway, for now, I agree to close this PR and just see what happens.

comments.author: gorryfair
comments.body: Fine to add something? but we'd need to converge - or can we capture this as a comment in the source - I think something along these lines is going to work out as what we need.

comments.author: tomhenderson
comments.body:
> Fine to add something? but we'd need to converge - or can we capture this as a comment in the source - I think something along these lines is going to work out as what we need.

I am fine with postponing this in order to meet the deadline.

comments.author: mwelzl
comments.body:
I suggest to close this PR because we don't need it: pacing should work with the rules as they are. If I'm not mistaken, they allow for anything below a full RTT of ACK ignorance (I mean: not increasing cwnd when ACKs arrive), followed by immediately increasing cwnd as the congestion control rules allow (e.g., +1 in Reno CA or *2 in slow start). Pacing should never take breaks as long as that - it's always at sub-RTT time scales (and: why would we want to allow even larger time scales?).

My suggestion would be to make this clearer in text instead.

reviews.author: gorryfair
reviews.body:
This is an imprecise MUST implement statement, which is never so great. I think that would need to be reworded as a required response not a required to implement.

I agree there is a tricky condition to pin-down, but I am not sure this helps yet, and susepct we could make progress and define this later?

pulls.title: Editorial improvments to 00.
pulls.author: gorryfair
pulls.body:
Adds DCCP
Updates QUIC
Also adds a change log

comments.body: This is WAY better

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body:
Many thanks for doing this, IMO it's a great improvement!
I just have a few small suggestions. Also, I think that, after merging this, RFC 4341 should probably be added to the list of "updates" in the document header?

comments.body:
```suggestion
>Cubic doesn't increase cwnd when it's limited by the sending application or rwnd.
```

I suggest to undo this because it's a literal quote. This is really how it's written in the RFC.
Maybe put it under quotation marks?

```suggestion
The exception for pacing in the second paragraph requires that pacing is enabled, this is specifically taken into account. Pacing could occur over various timescales, but
```

This is either a nit that you overlooked, or it's just my English: it may well be correct?  I just don't know.

```suggestion
A DCCP Congestion Control ID (CCID) specifing TCP-like behaviour ought to follow the method specified in this document. The current guidance relates only to !RFC2861.
```
.... ~mangled ~ ... I'll untangle.

/quite large/arbitrarily large/ ?
/application limited/rate-limited/ as per RFC 7661 ?
/low rate/rate lower than permitted by the cwnd/
/RFC2861/RFC7661/
/not be/is not/
/application limited/rate-limited/ as per RFC 7661 ?
/the congestion window is not being fully utilized./the sender if not fully utilising the congestion window./
All of this is a literal quote from RFC 4341!
See a short PR that tries to undo some of the legacy of re41 and 2861. Note 2861 can't be normative.

pulls.title: Discussion of rate-based control and pacing
pulls.author: mwelzl

comments.body:
Rather than say 'This is only one way to constrain the rate of the sender`, I suggest `Use of a congestion window variable to control sending rate is not the only mechanism available and used in practice.'

To me, it is clearer to avoid the ambiguous 'This' in the current sentence.

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body:
Many thanks, LGTM!

If you agree, let's merge both now?

pulls.title: Fix typos in Introduction (fixes Issue #27)
pulls.author: mohittahiliani
pulls.body: Fixes two typos in the first paragraph of the Introduction Section.

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body: Also a great catch, many thank for the fix!

pulls.title: Remove duplicate statement (fixes Issue #28)
pulls.author: mohittahiliani
pulls.body:
maxFS is defined twice: once in Section 1.1 and then in Section 3 with the same statement -- "the largest value of FlightSize since the last time that cwnd was decreased. If cwnd has never been decreased, maxFS is the maximum value of FlightSize since the start of the data transfer."

This PR removes the definition from Section 3.

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body: Great catch, and a good fix, many thanks!

comments.body: What about instead saying that RFC 9002 is consistent with this draft, and no specific update is needed?  I don't think of the second paragraph in Section 7.8 as an unnecessary limitation; I view it as an implementation clarification in the same way that the distinction between FlightSize and cwnd may need to be clearly understood in implementations.

Ahh, I see, this is quite unclear text from me. I agree that the unnecessary pacing limitation is not related to the second paragraph of Section 7.8 of RFC 9002, even though it certainly reads that way.  I do think we need to update RFC 9002 because, like the other specs we update, it's unnecessarily strict - it doesn't allow cwnd to grow based on maxFS as we do.

I'll propose an update.

pulls.title: Neal's suggested use of "limit" instead of "inc", and ACK Neal.
pulls.author: mwelzl

pulls.title: Simplify the writeup on rules (fixes Issue #40)
pulls.author: mohittahiliani

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body: Many thanks, this is good!  Two suggestions, please take a look.

comments.body:
```suggestion
1. MUST apply a constraint on the growth of cwnd
```

```suggestion
In rule #2, the function limit() returns the maximum cwnd value the congestion control algorithm would yield by increasing from the value of the maxFS parameter within one RTT.
```
/MUST constrain the growth of cwnd/ / ?

```suggestion
1. MUST constrain the growth of cwnd
```

```suggestion
1. MUST constrain the growth of cwnd.
```

```suggestion
2. SHOULD cap cwnd to be no larger than limit(maxFS).
```

```suggestion
3. MAY restrict maxFS as min(maxFS, pipeACK), using "pipeACK" as defined in {{!RFC7661}}.
```

pulls.title: Add co-author name
pulls.author: mohittahiliani
pulls.body:
Added name as a co-author.

Resolves #46

comments.body: "incoming" or "received"?

```suggestion
where cwnd and SMSS follow their definitions in {{!RFC5681}}, which states that N "is the number of previously unacknowledged bytes acknowledged in the incoming ACK".
```
See my suggestion (open in browser I think, since it seems you commented on the old text, not the new?!)
The point of this is to clarify that this is the original wording from RFC 5681. I don't think we should attempt to massage that text instead, since it's copy+pasted from there.

pulls.title: Add an example in Section 3 (fixes #39)
pulls.author: mohittahiliani
pulls.body: Note: as discussed during our call with Michael, the example has been added in Section 3 directly instead of putting it in Section 3.1 (which is Discussion).

comments.body:
```suggestion
We illustrate the working of the rules by showing the increase of cwnd in two scenarios: when the growth of cwnd is unconstrained, and when it is constrained by the increase rules. In both cases we assume initial cwnd (initcwnd) = 10 segments, a single connection begins with Slow Start, the sender transmits a total of 14 segments but pauses after transmitting 10 segments and resumes the transmission for the remaining 4 segments afterwards, no packets are lost, and an ACK is sent for every packet.
```

```suggestion
Initially, cwnd = initcwnd = 10 segments. The sender transmits 10 segments and pauses. Since the sender is in the Slow Start phase, the arrival of an ACK for each of the 10 segments increases the cwnd by 1 segment, resulting in the cwnd increasing to 20 segments. Subsequently, after the pause, the sender transmits 4 segments and pauses again. As a consequence, the arrival of 4 ACKs results in cwnd further increasing to 24 segments even though the sender is rate-limited.
```

```suggestion
Initially, cwnd = initcwnd = 10 segments. The sender transmits 10 segments and pauses; note that FlightSize and maxFS are 10 segments at this point. Since the sender is in the Slow Start phase, the arrival of an ACK for each of the 10 segments increases the cwnd by 1 segment, resulting in cwnd increasing to 20 segments. Subsequently, when the sender resumes and transmits 4 segments, rule #1 constrains the growth of cwnd because FlightSize < cwnd and rule #2 caps cwnd to be no larger than limit(maxFS) = 2*maxFS = 2*10 segments = 20 segments.
```

reviews.author: mwelzl
reviews.body: Many thanks!  Looks good to me

comments.body:
do we want to finish the thought?:
...is rate-limited (i.e., has never sent more than 10 segments/RTT).
I agree with Gorry's proposed extension above and with this MR in general

```suggestion
Initially, cwnd = initcwnd = 10 segments. The sender transmits 10 segments and pauses. Since the sender is in the Slow Start phase, the arrival of an ACK for each of the 10 segments increases the cwnd by 1 segment, resulting in the cwnd increasing to 20 segments. Subsequently, after the pause, the sender transmits 4 segments and pauses again. As a consequence, the arrival of 4 ACKs results in cwnd further increasing to 24 segments even though the sender is rate-limited (i.e., has never sent more than 10 segments/RTT)..
```

```suggestion
Initially, cwnd = initcwnd = 10 segments. The sender transmits 10 segments and pauses. Since the sender is in the Slow Start phase, the arrival of an ACK for each of the 10 segments increases the cwnd by 1 segment, resulting in the cwnd increasing to 20 segments. Subsequently, after the pause, the sender transmits 4 segments and pauses again. As a consequence, the arrival of 4 ACKs results in cwnd further increasing to 24 segments even though the sender is rate-limited (i.e., has never sent more than 10 segments/RTT).
```
Done, change applied - and thanks!!
